claim.hypothesis: Relaxation during the weekend is positively associated with joviality [at the end of the following week]
claim.hypothesis_location: Recovery and Affect section, Hypothesis 1a, p.1142
claim.statement: The claim is tested with data from a longitudinal survey of preschool teachers by regressing participants' joviality at the end of the workweek on their level of relaxation during the previous weekend and their joviality before the previous weekend, as well as measures of detachment, mastery, control, and hassles (all during the previous weekend); and controls for age, gender, having children, work hours per week, and workdays per week. The test demonstrated that relaxation significantly predicted joviality (β = 0.15, p < 0.01)
claim.statement_location: Results section, Relaxation and affect, p.1148; also Table 2

data.source: pen-and-paper survey including: Recovery Experience Questionnaire (Sonnentag & Fritz, 2007); Positive and Negative Affect Schedule-X (Watson & Clark, 1994); a 53-item checklist of possible hassles (DeLongis, Folkman, & Lazarus, 1988)
data.access_details: questionnaires: Sonnentag, S., & Fritz, C. (2007). The recovery experience questionnaire: Development and validation of a measure for assessing recuperation and unwinding from work. Journal of Occupational Health Psychology, 12, 204–221. Watson, D., & Clark, L. A. (1994). The PANAS-X: Manual for the positive and negative affect schedule - expanded form. University of Iowa. DeLongis, A., Folkman, S., & Lazarus, R. S. (1988). The impact of daily stress on health and mood: Psychological and social resources as mediators. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 54, 486–495. no details about the data access.
data.notes: There seems to be a significance mismatch: the text reports p < .01, but Table 2 shows β = 0.15 with p < .05; the p < .01 appears to refer to the Step-3 change in R2 (delta R2), not the individual relaxation coefficient. It is a longitudinal study with repeated measures.

method.description: This longitudinal (three measurements: survey packages were mailed to organizations and completed surveys mailed back to the researchers) study examined how specific recovery experiences during the weekend (relaxation, mastery, control, and detachment), as well as non-work hassles, were associated with specific positive and negative affective states during the following workweek.
method.steps: 1. Prepare the materials: - three separate surveys (for Time 1, Time 2, Time 3); Time 1 (Friday) for  demographics and baseline affective states (measured with Positive and Negative Affect Schedule-X; (1 = ‘‘not at all’’ to 5 = ‘‘very much’’); Time 2 (Sunday evening) for  weekend recovery experiences (measured with Recovery Experience Questionnaire; five-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = ‘‘not at all’’ to 5 = ‘‘very much’’.), non-work hassles (measured with a 53-items checklist of possible hassles; (1 = not at hassle at all to 5 = a big hassle), and affective states; Time 3 (following Friday) measures affective states during the workweek. - instructions,  - stamped return envelopes. 2. Contact heads of preschools, obtain consent for participation and mail survey packages directly to each organization for distribution. 3. Match surveys per participant using a participant-generated identification code and exclude participants with missing surveys. 4. Perform hierarchical regression analysis in three steps: - Step 1: include only demographics (gender, age, having children, work hours per week, workdays per week) - Step 2: add baseline joviality (Time 1) - Step 3: add weekend experiences (relaxation, detachment, mastery, control) and non-work hassles (Time 2). 5. For the result in question specifically, regress joviality at Time 3 on: joviality at Time 1, relaxation, detachment, mastery, control, non-work hassles (Time 2) and demographics (gender, age, having children, work hours per week, workdays per week).
method.control_variables: gender, age, having children, work hours per week, workdays per week, the level of joviality at Time 1
method.tools_software: not stated (LISREL is mentioned for the CFA but no info about regression)

numerical_results.p_value: p < .01 is reported in the text. Table 2 shows p < .05 (please see notes).

metadata.original_paper_title: The weekend matters: Relationships between stress recovery and affective experiences.
